content.description: Start out by matching a heel-toe cam in the hueco from a sit start.  From there, move up through a pocket and pinch/gaston.  At this point, work the remaining slab crimps to reach a solid jug and topout.
content.protection: Pad or two and a spot, landing is great though. It climbs just left of Elastic Time.
content.location: It is on the North-face of Crazy Diamond Boulder.

content.description: This is a solid, overhanging boulder with potential for lots of problems, if it hasn't been established already. Start on two good crimps, figure out your feet placement and throw to a good pocket about 4 feet away. Your feet will cut so be ready. After that, grab some slopers (or there's a crimp and a sloper option) and top out. The huecos are huge, but it's really about where you're getting your feet when you top out. After that, it's cake.
content.protection: A pad (or more) and spotter is good.
content.location: The problem is just about in the middle of the boulder's overhanging face. Right now, it's got lots of chalk on it, so it's easy to find. Downclimb on the northwest side with some big pockets.

content.description: Stand start with hands matched on the lip. From there, throw a heel up, gain the sloping hueco, mantel on to the slab, and finish straight up the vertical crack.
content.protection: A pair of pads. This has a good landing, but rocks surround the fall zone.
content.location: It climbs the center of Crazy Diamond's east face.

content.description: Sit start on the low pale ledge down and slightly right of the three large dishes on the upper face. Get your feet up and cross to a downturned sloper. Reset your feet, and throw for the massive horizontal rail up and right. Keep that core tight as to avoid a little booty scooty or a dab. Everyone will see it, and it won't count. Work from the rail straight up on good holds to a slightly delicate topout.
content.protection: Pads if you want your feet dabbing all day, otherwise joint health be dammed.
content.location:
Start just to the right of

Tom's White Fence

on the low square edge, and move up and right to the less pronounced pockets on the positive face.

content.description: Starts on the north side arete (the right side if you're staring at the overhanging face). Follow the crimps up to a glorious rail. Turn the corner on the rail and follow it to its natural end, and start to move up using a coral like pocket and a left handed hold. Topping out isn't bad, it was just nerve wracking for us.
content.location: The route starts on the right arete by the overhung side of the boulder. Downclimb is on the north side further down the boulder. There's a little tree growing out of the top of the boulder right where the downclimb is.

content.description: Sit start with hands at your choice of hold at the large huecos. From there, stand up to a right hand edge with a thumb catch, bump the left hand up to a sidepull-undercling, bump the left again to a another edge, gain your feet, and finish up the remaining slab on an assortment of edges and a pocket for an easy mantel.
content.protection: A pair of pads. It has a great immediate fall zone, but there is a tree behind the problem.
content.location: It climbs just to the right of Virtual Function on Crazy Diamond's north face.

content.description:
Diamond Techno has a very hard to read sequence with seemingly non-existent holds.

Please let me know if you know of a FA or name!
content.location: I did a sit start with my left hand on a sloper, my right hand on a undercling/sidepull, and a left heel hook.

content.description:
This one may be a bit harder than advertised, but it seemed like new beta could come out of the woodwork at any minute.

Pull on with a jug, and immediately start crimping the very tiny holds on really nice rock! I topped out up and right thinking it originally went more right, ended up climbing more to the left. I used my original top out to the right on the send, but the left topout is likely easier if cleaned up.

The name comes from finding a shank-shaped piece of bone from a deer leg at the base of the climb.
content.location: Start on a large jug and crimp towards the bottom of the boulder. Climb up an obtuse corner on very bad crimp edges with huge feet.

content.description:
Diamond Arete uses a desperado toe hook.

If you know of an FA party or name, please let me know and i will update the climb!
content.location: Sit start on some crimps at the base of the overhanging arete, do a few intro moves into a massive jug, then figure out how to go straight up the arete followingÂ  it to the top of the boulder on questionable, lichen covered rock.

content.description:
2 hard crimp moves lead to a mantel. This has huge feet and uses LOTS OF CORE!

Please let me know if you know of a FA or name!
content.location:
Just left of the start holds on "

Tom's White Fence

" lies a couple of crimps, start here, and go up and left out a very steep overhang to a tricky-to-mount slab.
